author: @jcf3300
text: @sentdex @HarrisonK -- I think what I like the most about you via your channel & site is your genuine approach. The fact that you publish your material in its raw form is SOOO useful to those starting out and/or needing inspiration. Your coding sessions, like this one in particular, remind me a lot of my own, which makes watching these videos all he more helpful. And while you might catch heat for "lack of elegance" or "try/except logic approach" etc., you get the job done, which some people that dog you might forget in their own coding lives. Namely, solving a computational problem is what programming is FOR (at least from an engineering standpoint). That is, tackle the problem first even if ad-hoc, THEN refactor and make readable; don't mistake the forest from the trees. Anyway, here's a shotout to your presentation style and your ability to get things done. Please, keep it up.

author: @eyaldar
text: It would seem that the way to get a bunch of tickers all at the same time doesn't work very well when the batches are too big, not sure why though... Anyway to anyone who wants to know, you would right it pretty much the same: quandl.get(["WIKI/A", "WIKI/AA",...], start_date="2000-12-12", end_date="2014-12-30", authtoken=auth_tok) and then you would get one gaint data frame where each stock columns are written like this, for example AAPL would be: "AAPL - Adj. Close".  I guess there is also the "get_table" option but I didn't want to use it...

author: @RafalMankaPL
text: when using python threading, requesting quandl for putting the csv file together takes around 5 minutes. Agree, the code is messy, but if you would put up a class together, that will introduce next layer of complexity to the problem which is not the subject of this course. Great stuff!

author: @mjoass
text: The problem found around the 20 minute mark was that we had changed row = sp500_df[(sp500_df.index to be row = sp500_1y[(sp500_1y.index   When you copy paste the code at the 22 minute mark this is fixed :)
